content:
It happened again and this is the response from my hosting server.

Thank you for contacting Support. Reviewing logs on the server against times when your IP was blocked, it appears to be related to SMTP syntax errors. Here's an example of the one of the log entries


2024-04-10 06:40:59.381 [2938868] SMTP syntax error in "\026\003\003?\257\001??\253\003\003f\026l\273\3772\275\024vZ!\035\021\265\247\300'\371\237\217\300\224\344\227\302p\211y\177\254U}??*\300,\300+\3000\300/?\237?\236\300$\300#\300(\300'\300" H=[172.56.69.99]:58735 I=[209.182.196.85]:587 NUL character(s) present (shown as '?') 2024-04-10 06:40:59.381 [2938868] SMTP syntax error in "\300 \300\024\300\023?\235?\234?=?

Unfortunately it would be difficult to determine what is causing this, but it would indicate a problem with data being sent by your mail client. It could be related to configuration settings in your mail client or invalid or unrecognized characters or symbols in a recipient email address, email subject, or email body. We would advise reviewing your mail client settings, email addresses you are sending to, and/or anything that may be frequently sent (it could potentially be something included in an email signature even).

content:
I think you have it David.

A commercial provider that is not on "on premises" that does not require a password or use internal network authorizations for SMTP will be about as common as Martian on the side of the road with a hand sign advertising free rides to the moon. There are still a couple of providers out there that have no password on SMTP, but require authentication via POP with a password from the same address in the last few minutes to allow a send. But any account configured with password none is almost certainly incorrectly configured. There are exceptions, but not many and not common use cases.

In the case of inmotion hosting, they certainly require authentication. 

   Incoming Server: secure##.inmotionhosting.com.    Outgoing Server: secure##.inmotionhosting.com.    Username: Your full e-mail address.    Password: Your e-mail account password.    Incoming Port: POP3 995 or IMAP 993.    Outgoing Mail server (SMTP) Port: 465.    SSL: YES.    SMTP Authentication Required.

Open relays basically died a horrible death in the 1990s thanks to their use in SPAM and general abuse https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_mail_relay
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
• Update***

I've got it working; it seems like you have to save contacts "manually" first in both apps before it knows how to synchronize between the two automatically. I saved a test contact in Gmail called "Test Contact 1" and it synchronized to Thunderbird; thereafter I saved a contact in Thunderbird called "Test Contact 2" After saving in Thunderbird both "Test Contact 1 & Test Contact 2" were finally updated to Gmail and synchronized across my devices.

content:
You are talking about folders that 'Sort by' > 'Threaded'. Sounds like you are using 'collased' as your default settings.

On the 'Menu Bar' toolbar: This maybe your current setting.

  • 'View' > 'Threads' > 'Collapse all threads'.

I suggest you select:

  • 'View' > 'Threads' > 'Expand all threads'

Worth noting the Shortcut keys:

  • The quick way to 'Expand all threads' is to press the * key.
  • The quick way to 'Collapse all threads' is to press the \ key.

If you have set 'all threads as expanded' in a folder and then exit Thunderbird. The next time you start up Thunderbird it should auto remember that set up.

So it should remember whether all are set as expanded or all set as collapsed. But if you have all expanded and you collapse one or two, you will find when you restart it does not remember the individual email setting.

If you find your session data etc is not being saved/remembered correctly: First check to see what programs you have got installed which are allowed to scan your thunderbird profile folders. Many Anti-Virus and other clean-up software like CCleaner or Wisecleaner should not have any access to your Profile folders because they can delete session, password etc files and if Anti-Virus can scan files, it will cause a slow down in processes. If you let a AV scan your profile then if it finds a problem never let it fix it because you stand a good chance of losing a lot of emails. If you do want to use those types of products then I would suggest you make Thunderbird profile folder exempt from scanning.

content:
The issue is basically everyone thinks user access control should be on a per application basis. Fundamantally this might have some merit on shared computers where the user has no user account to protect them, but that is not really a Thunderbird issue. It is an overall security issue.

Hence when told Thunderbird's primary password only encrypts and protects their saved passwords they are ready to try and argue the point that it should do more. Personally I can't think of anything sillier. But it is a popular view. You might want to share in on the feedback forum where others have already suggested their idea as to what should happen. https://connect.mozilla.org/t5/ideas/primary-password-was-master-password-to-block-access-to/idi-p/25967
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Well, if Thunderbird is still installed, you might try this first: Choose Tools -> Developer Tools > Error Console, paste the expression: 

openDialog("chrome://pippki/content/resetpassword.xul")   and press the Evaluate button. That will open a dialog asking you if you want to reset your password. If Evaluate is not seen, press enter key.

That normally restores Thunderbird without passwords.

content:
AOL suggests these settings, but what they do not mention is your password or authentication type.

AOL and the parent Yahoo have been requiring the use of oauth authentication for a long time now. Unfortunately verizon was in such a hurry to shove their mail out the door, they didn't get that part complete.

There is a workaround of using the server name for AOL, which AOL give as; Incoming mail server (POP3): pop.aol.com Port 995 using SSL/TLS Outgoing mail server (SMTP): smtp.aol.com Port 465 using SSL/TLS.

Once the server names are updated, restart Thunderbird and then change the authentication method.

content: I am no guru on this, but I'll offer my thoughts: From my experience, some email providers establish their own names for folders, such as 'Drafts' instead of 'Draft'. My approach on the draft folder, for example, would be to log on to the online account and create a draft there, and then (assuming IMAP), see in what draft folder it appears in Thunderbird. Then, I would change the Thunderbird setting to use that Draft folder. Now, I would delete the folders from online account and restart thunderbird and delete them there. That has worked for me.
creator: davidsk
